The space was very clean, I can see a foodie having a reception here, no problem.  I like the location, as their are a few bars around, and there is a street trolley right outside as well.  Maybe Friday's are off days in the markets in CLT, who the hell knows...  Oh yea, and I still had to pay $2 for parking, only there for 18 minutes (if that). As I just read another Yelper's review, he said that there is parking validation there... Nice Tom, nice...  I have seen bigger and better in other cities, but if it is a great fit for the city, then more power to them!

The 7th Street Market is an awesome little market boasting some very impressive food and drink options. Literally everything in the market is within your line of sight. I went early Sunday morning to grab coffee at Not Just Coffee and breakfast at Local Loaf. The coffee is top quality and Local Loaf does French breakfast unlike anything I've had before. The chicken and egg biscuit is a must try at Local Loaf. It is amazingly good. There's also  a really good crepe place called Hazelnut crepes that serves some fantastic cooking crepes. Various other local vendors are there selling local products as well. Overall, it's just a fun and delicious local market that's a must visit when in Charlotte.

As an outsider, I dont get why other reviewers are so excited about this place. For a farmers market, this place has a limited selection & overpriced goods. For a shopping spot, I found it totally lacking. It may be good for a lunch spot if you work in the area. They did a great job if this is what the place was intended to be, but I wouldn't have waste your time on a special trip here.

What a great little spot to pick up some local fare.. -Local cheeses -Local Fruits/Veggies -Local treats (baked goods, honey, crackers) -Local Juice/ Vegan Fare -Local Grass fed beef & fresh local seafood -Wine & Beer -flowers  -coffee -sushi -pizza -other foods... (take & bake, prepared etc.)  They come at a bit of a higher price point but overall you're strengthening the community you live in and getting to try some really unique/high quality products.  Most vendors proudly offered samples and  I even noticed a sign for wine-tasting. They also took debit, though I'm sure cash is preferred.   I love that parking is validated though the process has thrown some for a loop. Park. Shop up to 90 minutes, RIGHT BEFORE YOU LEAVE - (and before your 90min is up) Validate using the machine across from the sushi joint by the door. You will then have 20 minutes from that moment to drive through the exit gate. It definitely is a little process but it is so worth it.  I'll certainly come again...and this time I'm buying some of that fabulous cheese I sampled : )

Family favorite with something for everyone. We got a bit addicted to going here on Sundays and had to cut back not.  The acacia bowls are very good with all fresh ingredients. And I love the salads and soups from local loaf.   On the way out we pick up a bag of popcorn. Try the fried chicken... it'll surprise you. They need to be selling this stuff in theaters.

This market really has it all y'all. I imagine it'd be nice to visit during the weekdays but I've only ever visited on the weekends with my schedule. It gets fairly crowded around lunch time on Saturday and Sunday. There really is a little bit of everything. If you can't find it here you'll find it within walking distance fairly close by. There's a parking garage where I've never been without a parking space. Bring your ticket with you to the market because you can get it validated there. Take the light rail to here or from here - it stops right outside the doors. Also you must know the little Easter Egg on the outside of the building. Find the red panels with handprints on them and slap your hand there to light up the side of the whole building and play a funky sound.  Moving inside, where do I begin? Restaurant options include sushi, sandwiches and bread, pizza and Italian. Along the way you'll find coffee, tea, beer and even a juice bar. Towards the back there are a few permanent-ish shops with southern style knick-knacks, spices, chocolates, wine and collectibles. There are even a few bicycles for sale hanging from the ceiling. There aren't a whole lot of tables inside but for nicer days there's probably just as many outside that you can expand onto. At the front near the door there seem to be a few small boutique-like shops that are ever-rotating. Last I saw was a book-seller/exchange.  Prices vary though I'd say they're on the high-average end of things. My favorite restaurant is Local Loaf. I'm also a sucker for the expensive juices at Viva Raw. I have to get back in here for a beer too. Depending on which shop you find yourself at the staff friendliness varies. They often seem just overwhelmed by the sheer volume of people in here. It can get loud and anxiety inducing so you might want to stay away if that kind of environment stresses you out.

I just love this place. I really do. I can really appreciate a spot where I can get a bowl of fruits and granola and my boyfriend can get a giant sandwich/pizza/whatever and everyone is happy and no one compromises. And Not Just Coffee lives here too-- which if you haven't tried any of their locations-- do yourself a favor and go right now.   I like to walk around before/after eating something delicious from Rico's or Local Loaf. They have cute crafty stuff, cheese and wine, fresh vegetables, and pimento cheese. There are tables in the middle, but I prefer to eat outside with my pup.

I love this place.  If you're into supporting your fellow Charlottean or North Carolinian (as you should be) then 7th Street Public Market is the place to be.  Located immediately off the light rail line, it's a place for local people buying local things made from local products.  They care about the details that go into their craft, not just the finished product.  Organic, local, handmade, small farm, all things that these vendors care so much about.  My favorite shops here are:  NOT JUST COFFEE - DUH!  Just go there. ORRMAN'S CHEESE SHOP - Rachel knows her cheese and her cheese makers.  Get a sample and pick up some other local specialties here (i.e. Cloister Honey). LOCAL LOAF - Awesome breakfast and lunch.  Fresh bread.  What more do you need?! GREENEMAN FARMS - Local food for local people.  From produce to milk and eggs to preserves.  I love this place.  Seriously, go there!

Sue me, I like flea markets. I really like indoor markets, such as Lexington Market in Baltimore, New Castle Market in Delaware and Reading Terminal in Philadelphia.  I wish that Charlotte had something similar. It's not a farmer's market, though there are similarities - it's a meeting place, a food bazaar (and bizarre in some cases). It's just a bunch of shops, probably more similar to an indoor flea market. Charlotte, being as upscale as we think we are, have a bunch of upscale-like shops (many of which are), and that's a good thing - but it's a small market. Much like Atherton, you can walk through the whole thing in ten minutes.  Spend your time wisely. Get a coffee, a grilled cheese, and take some salt or tea home, but even with that you're likely to come out with time to spare on the free validated parking in the garage.

Every time we go here, there are more businesses sprouting inside. We started off with Not Just Coffee which is a nice little coffee bar, and of course, my absolute favorite, Pure Pizza. There is a sushi place, desserts (cakes and ice cream), deli and juice bar, all of which look real good. They also have a spice shop, a salt shop (salts of the world), wine and beer shop, fresh meat and seafood, fruits & veggies. The good thing about this is, even if I'm eating at pure pizza, I can bring my coffee cup or glass of wine over as long as I bring it back.  They also validate parking for 90 minutes, but be careful, twice the machine failed to print the validation bar code and we had to pay for parking.

I can't believe this was my first time here. Nice area with a good selection of things to eat or drink. Came here with some out of towners and they loved the whole experience. We did some shopping. Got some hot drinks and walked around a bit. I decided to get some hot chocolate and it was so good! There are lots of tables to sit. Everyone we encountered was super friendly. I would love to come here again and try something else out!

Cool concept, slight miss on execution. Half the booths are closed on Sunday. No designated parking just for the market, we got turned away across the street by the church organization. Parking garage closest to it charges $2 per 20 minutes.

I just love 7th Street Market. If you have visitors coming into Charlotte, take them here! It has a great vibe to it. There are lots of places to eat from fruit and yogurt bowls, to sushi, to gourmet pizza, to crepes. There is a farmers market, bakery, wine shop, juice shop, and jam shop. There is a little something for everyone. Also if you get your parking validated, you can park in the garage for two hours for free! What a deal :)

I get physically angry when people tell me that they've never been here. Okay, maybe that is an exaggeration. Or maybe it's not. *Shakes fist in air. Get off my lawn*  First of all, they have a validation machine for parking at Seventh Street Station. That's right, FREE PARKING IN UPTOWN. The validation machine is located on a shelf to the left side of Bonsai Sushi Fusion. Just stick your ticket in and go. TWSS. Warning: validation is only good for 90 minutes of free parking. So, move your car every hour and a half if you need longer. There is also a light rail stop here.   The only problem I have with this place is that I can easily drop $40 quickly because there are so many amazing vendors here. There's a little bit of everything here and I want it all.   Not Just Coffee: my favorite place for a caffeine fix. The lattes are works of art.  Pure Pizza: farm to fork concept. The chorizo will change your life. Viva Raw: fresh pressed juices. Not sure which one you'll like? They'll let you sample to see! The beet juice is my favorite. Tank's Tap: great selection of local beers. Local Loaf: lunch or brunch, they're both delicious. Try the signature chicken and the egg or the biscuits and gravy. Bonsai Sushi Fusion: super creative rolls, including a sushi burrito.  I could go on forever. There's not a bad vendor here. Assorted Table Wine Shop, Orrman's Cheese Shop, Hazelnut's Creperie, Cloud 9 Confections and more. You can even get amazing treats from barChocolate. I highly recommend the ghost chili ones. They are so unique and delicious.   I am so happy that uptown not only has such a great market like this, but they put a lot of support into it. I can't wait to see how this place continues to grow with the new park going up across the street. A moment of silence for Dixie's, please....

For such an early review, you have to take it for what it is. 7th Street Market is still under construction, and not all of the tenants have completed their spaces yet.  That said, this is something Charlotte has been yearning for. It's a huge open space where Ried's used to be with a dozen or so stalls that feature local businesses and an wealth of organic, locally sourced and sustainable food. Bakeries, butchers, produce, coffee, wine, pizza, and a second location for Fran's Filling Station, plus more to come. On my visits (I've been a couple of times so far), there has been live music and an interesting mix of people hanging out in the seating areas central to the space. It takes on the feel of a big-city farmer's market and is the perfect spot to spend an afternoon.    I've very interested to see how much more vibrant the market becomes once it's completely finished!
Cute enough. It needs more vendors. It has the potential to be a Chelsea Market in NYC.

Whenever we are visiting Charlotten we start our day here.  It's a fantastic group of local and regional farmers, food artisans, and entrepreneurs with more than 15 restaurants and shops.  Our favorites were Local Loaf (try the Croque Madame!) and Not Just Coffee.  They also have a creperie and bakery as well as a cheese shop (with gourmet grilled cheese!), sushi bar, pizza counter, and cocktail bar for lunch and dinner.

Cute market place. Good to hang out with friends for some food, beers and wine. But the main object is to shop. As this stuff is ridiculously expensive and totally overpriced, I do not shop here. But I love to browse and enjoy the ambiance when hanging out with friends here for coffee or beer. One thing that is worth shopping for here, is the local honey, the wine (expensive but great and rare choices) and the local/organic produce/fruits/meat. Sometimes you can score a great deal there. Nicely located uptown right next to the light rail and hopefully in the summer, I will be able to enjoy the outside area as well.

This place is an embarrassment of riches, and one stop that I always recommend to virtually all visitors and newcomers to Charlotte because it's got so many great small businesses under one (conveniently located) roof.  Need a last minute gift? Dying for caffeine fix? Rough day at the office and you really need a (craft) beer? Want to assemble the perfect cheese board? And pair it with the perfect wine because you're fancy? Taking a group to lunch but somebody's on a juice cleanse and everyone is craving something different?  7th Street Public Market has got your back.

Hello friends,  I'm trying to review for the meat market located in the back.   Alllllllrightyyyy Theeeen  Finally I have found what I've been looking for. A selection of different kind of meats. No no noooo not the regular chicken, beef, turkey, duck. They have a pretty nice assortment of different meats. Clean and void of foul smells. Looked pretty fresh (all yelp reviews aren't complete without "Freshest" in it). Now I met my "Fresh" quota I can proceed.   A few guys in the back chopping & packin. I don't wanna repeat what others may have already wrote. However, I ran with Aligator (1LB = 16.99) & Turtle (1LB = 6.99) yeah yeah yeah ohh not turtle. Yes!! Lol  I'll be back most def!  TTFN

I really love this place. They have a variety of natural foods from local farmers, vegan dishes, fresh seafood, and much more. I was able to purchase local honey, a bottle of sweet red (wine), and eat a veggie pizza. The environment is laid back. I never have a bad experience. The cost of products are reasonable.

After spending time at Abbeydale, we decided to head over to 7th Street to grab lunch.  The place was packed! Great weather brought folks out early!  We had an Acai bowl which was perfect for a light early lunch.  I walked around to see about produce anddddd I couldn't find any?? The market now just consists of placed to eat, grab coffee or a beer, wine cheeses and juices from viva raw. There was a section that was covered up so perhaps more items were under there?  Nonetheless,  it was great to get out and hang out at 7th street!

This is a really great and fun thing to do on he weekends with family and friends.  There are many cool places to check out for food, coffee, wine, and dessert.  There is so much quality food to eat!! I love food, obviously, so I was pretty impressed.  The market it walkable and does get crowded on the weekends. They validate parking for 90 minutes and there is a self scanner to scan your parking ticket, so don't forget before you leave!  You have to park in the garage right next door for the validation   The people are friendly and the atmosphere is awesome!  Great place to people watch!  I came recently and hope to be visiting again soon!

This place is a favorite, especially with a group of people with different tastes.  Sushi, Crepe, beer, coffee, cheese, sandwiches, pizza, wine, deli.... its got a great variety.  Not fancy, not expensive, just a bunch of local small businesses worthy of our support. AND, parking at the 7th street garage is free (up to 90 minutes).

Discovered 7th Street Market after trying to find "Not Just Coffee"....I didn't realize it was located in the market.  First time there it was close to closing time so a lot of the shops had already closed up.  Had some awesome coffee and my wife got a pastry from "Cloud 9 Bakery"....which she loved!  We went back last weekend around 3:00pm on a Saturday and more stores were open (The market has new hours to stay open later on Sat and close on Sun) and it was busier.  We had some coffee to start, then tried "Pure Pizza" which was delicious and our new favorite pizza place, and finished off with a pastry.  The place is a real one-stop shop and has a great atmosphere.  I just wish that I lived closer to it (we live in a suburb north of Charlotte) so that we could go more often.    I would give a 5 star rating but I did have an issue with the free parking.  You are supposed to get 90mins free parking and they have little machines in the market to validate your ticket.  I validated it and everything appeared correct but when I went to leave the parking machine said that I owed $10.  I didn't think I had been there longer than the allotted free 90 mins but definitely not $10 longer.  So I ejected the card to try and take it to a real parking attendant but after ejecting it I looked over and saw there was no one in the booth....by that time another car pulled in behind me so I had to go ahead and use the automated pay kiosk. I re-inserted my ticket and all of the sudden the price was now $12.  I paid and left.  I am not sure if there was a problem with the validating machine or if something just screwed up..but the $12 parking did put a damper on our second visit (The first time we parked on the street).  So next time I will check the street first and then if I have to park in the garage...I will double check the validating!
It's ok, it needs more fresh produce somewhere in the market. there are nice vendors there, but it needs more market types.

Perfect destination for our party limo!  We had delicious popcorn to start (baskets supplied for serving), Pure Pizza for lunch (Gino is a rock star), and Cloud 9 cupcakes for dessert (vegan cupcakes and ice cream for girls with allergies). Party room kept our girls contained and sound proof. The assistance provided to pull this off was mind blowing, the extras I needed were given with no extra charge and everyone was more than happy to help. Everyone claimed this birthday was "amazing". The only suggestion would be to try to get in a few minutes early to decorate, we were pressed for time but in all honesty I don't think they noticed. Highly recommend this place if just for the excellent service with a smile. Thanks Chris!!!

The 7th Street Public Market in Charlotte is a food court of sorts. There are several restaurants, bakeries, wine shops and a market. This seemed like a good spot to sample several dishes from different venues.  I was interested in trying Pure Pizza since they seemed to advertise a relationship with Chris Bianco, of Pizzeria Bianco in Phoenix, which has been named the best pizza place in the country in numerous publications over the years. It turns out that the only similarity between Pure Pizza and Chris Bianco is that they use the same tomatoes. By looking at their pizzas, one can see that is where the similarity ends.  We ordered the T-Rex which includes bacon, sausage, pepperoni and ground beef. The pizza had a nice char, maybe too much in certain spots. The toppings were plentiful and evenly distributed. The crust was nice and chewy. If you are a meat lover this pizza is a winner.  At Local Loaf, we got the Chicken & the Egg, which is a deep fried boneless chicken breast sitting atop a mound of cheese, with a honey BBQ sauce. The sandwich also included a fried egg with a runny yolk of course. There must have been a mistake to my order as some sprouts ended up on the sandwich, LOL. This massive behemoth was sandwiched between a buttery biscuit. This isn't a sandwich that can be eaten without causing a serious mess. It hit all of the notes too: salty, sweet, fried, crunchy. It comes with a cucumber salad to help cut down on the sweetness of the honey BBQ sauce.  We finished the meal off with a Banana Nutella crepe at Hazelnut Crepes. The filling was plentiful, the banana ripe with streams of Nutella running throughout. The crepe itself was a little doughy, but good overall.  7th Street Marketplace is probably not a food destination on its own, but does a good job of servicing the downtown area during lunch time as the place was packed.  The food at the places we ate were well executed and fairly priced.

There's literally a little bit of everything: coffee, tea, raw foods, baked goods, meat, seafood, pizza, sushi, wine, cheese... The real issue is where my bed is going to go because I could totally live in this place...   I love the set-up... It's all indoors, but it's more like an open air market than a structured type of business... You can lazily meander about and experience everything... I can only imagine the energy on a busy Saturday morning...   I purchased a yummy and potent pour over from Not Just Coffee, turned around and picked up some Salsa Verde kale chips from the raw foods stand directly behind me... They also have some of those healthy, but interesting smoothies and give samples... Why not try something new?  I walked through the space where the wine is because they were closed and found a whoooooole butcher situation on the back end of the market... They have everything... Fresh meat and seafood, prepared and ready to cook meals, frozen options... It was mindboggling... There's a guy selling jams and preserves, a cheese stand that had a huge inventory of tasty looking choices... Oh! Pure Pizza!  They have a pizza with limes on it... I didn't get it but it's on my list... Cloud 9... Heavenly desserts... Just dreamy...  Bonsai Sushi Fusion blew my whole mind (check out the review for deets) and I'm thinking there's a guy with spices for some reason, but I'm not sure if I'm dreaming that quite honestly... I'm pretty sure there's a spice guy, though... Oh! And there's fruit!  I could see spending a whole morning in here... Especially if it's raining and I don't want to go to an outdoor market... This is a perfect alternative and a great choice for exploration...

Great place if you are trying to avoid chains and eat like the locals do. It's like an incubator for small business in Charlotte from sushi burritos to cheese from all over the world. The community gives you a chance to enjoy your food while meeting new people and figuring out what you're going to have next time. Conveniently locate doff of the 7th street light rail station and College Street in Uptown, it's a gem.

This is Charlotte to me!    Local produce, chefs, and people.  I could write a nice long lengthy review here but I think it would serve you best if I just told you that it is in my top 3 favorite places to hang out and get lunch, coffee, and unique locally-made gifts.    Not Just Coffee -- 10 out of 10.  (See my review)  Best coffe, chai, tea in Uptown.  Local Loaf -- 9 out of 10.  Fresh baked bagguettes and all around unique sandwich choices.  Fresh made on the spot chips and cucumber salad.  Try the steak sandwich - WOW!  The deli counter, the wine store, pure pizza, the fresh local produce, sushi....  They have it all!  If you stop there for a bite, you will thank me.  And whatever little gift you cant find for that one neighbor that you need to get something for.  Head over to the shop that sells unique blends of spices, popcorn, and teas.  Bam!  Count it!  Enjoy!  -Ian M.

Crepes were absolutely delicious I had the strawberry, banana Nutella crepe and it was delicious but! My friend ordered the curry chicken crepe and it took everything in me not to steal her plate it was SOOO delicious. Both were incredibly delicious and priced perfectly for the quality. Just go get some and stop reading this review! Haha

Such a great spot to bring out-of-town guests, eat, shop, and people-watch. It's right next to ImaginOn, so stop by here before/after you bring the kiddos there.   I've been a few times: the first time to try the Chicken and the Egg sandwich from Local Loaf (Cheerwine honey sauce, oh my god) and another time we ordered from Pure Pizza. The pizza was good, but I still haven't found any pizza joint in Charlotte that comes close to Lilly's Pizza in Raleigh. But they serve their pizza with a side of honey for your crust, which was an original touch. The market is bustling and lively and it could use more seating, but overall, I love the atmosphere.

This is a cool place to hang out when you've got time between meetings or just want to people watch for a bit. I first discovered the market when I found Not Just Coffee here in 2013. I got to try Pure Pizza & Tank's Taps on my last business trip in December 2014.   The market can get busy during the typical times (lunch hour, happy hour, etc) but it offers a little bit of everything to it's patrons. I haven't tried the Meat Market, but I've been very tempted. Next time through town I'll have to remember to pack a cooler to take things home with me. I've seen these 'markets' pop up in other cities and be successful. I yearn for the day Jacksonville can open one and have it succeed.

A cool little eat in Market in the heart of uptown. Have a drink, shop, eat or have a snack. Its go it all, even tea shirts. We experienced this as part of a Food De Tour and  loved walking around. Wish the free parking was just not an hour as we got no discount even thought we were validated. Park across the street for half the $$

Love this place! Great place to relax for a bit and is the perfect place to go if you want options or are with a group. I obviously didn't try every vendor but the layout & location are great, there's a ton of natural light and they validate your parking (from the attached garage) for the first 90minutes free.  Definitely try this place out for a unique market option downtown!

The market reminds me of a fancier farmers market and with AC in the summer and heat in the winter!! There are so many different food options..all of which are amazing. I love that everything is local!! Its great for families or if you have guest visiting out of town. Very casual and cute! Lots of seating! Dont be afraid to try something new! Also has a fee local shops/vendors to get some local NC Charlotte souvenirs,etc while stopping. Parking across the st or just a walk away from any side street parking! Be ready for a relaxing enjoying the town kind of day, and if you go here..a full belly at a resonable price!

This place was a disappointment. I admire the hard working local entrepreneurs who are trying to make a go with fairly unique products and service. The venue does not have much atmosphere and the products offered are not unique enough to justify the sometimes expensive prices.

I LOVE Public Market! Everything we have tried at the restaurants has been awesome! The small market is great and the outdoor seating is fun! Never had a bad experience. It can get REALLY crowded at lunch time any day, so if you would like to hang out and relax, you might go early or late.

This place is awesome! Lots of food vendors to chose from! We ordered pizza from a local farm pizza shop, food took a bit of time to get but it was Saturday afternoon, probably a normally very busy time. Sat at the counter of the tap house (? Not sure if that's what it was called), the bartender was a little on the rude side when we said we didn't want a beer menu, but the manger came around and was super nice as even took our dirty dishes. The place could expand, seating was very limited and it was very crowded and loud. The prices are a little on the high side, but it's understandable when these are small ma and pop shops.

Not quite Reading Terminal Market in Philly or Pikes Place in Seattle but a great spot for the Queen City!   It has just enough options to have everyone leaving happy and full! This is a great place for my wife and I to eat who can struggle at restaurants because I am a picky meat and potatoes kind of girl who doesn't like fish or seafood and she is tried and true pescatarian. I can choose a pizza from Pure, grilled cheese from Ormans Cheese Shop or a sweet Nutella filled crepe from Hazelnuts while she can enjoy Sushi at Bonsai Fusion or a fancy salad from Local Loaf all while washing it down with a local beer from Tank's Tap!  A few suggestions I have for newbies to the market is to 1) take a full loop around the market - survey your options, 2) check their hours before making a special trip their - for some reason they seem too short to me and some places close if it's slow, and 3) don't forget you can validate your parking as long as it's under 90 minutes!  Overall a SOLID choice for a place for all to eat in Uptown!

Great market downtown (uptown) .  Lots of different little shops are with in the market.  During my visit it look like that have some great butcher meats.   The only things i got while i was there was salt from "salts of the earth" and coffee at NOT JUST COFFEE.

Fun place to visit!  Something for everyone...Hungry?  Stop and any of the great food choices...pizza, sushi, cheese, fresh bread, sandwiches, chocolate, juice! Thirsty?  Coffee, tea, craft beer.  Need some meat for a meal?  Meat market...need some veggies?  Farm stand.  Cupcakes?  They got em.  Great for a big or picky group because there is much to choose from!

Next to a parking garage- it's a foodie's foodcourt. Lots of good choices with an upscale twist. Crepe's grilled cheeses, unique pizza's, couture coffee, wine shops and microbrews on tap.  It was a little crowded with families, but I came on a rainy day around 1pm. Pizza/garlic knots and crepes were delicious. Solid "quick bite" lunch type place. Something for everyone.

7th street market, I have such hopes for this place especially now that the light rail extension has opened. The first time I read about this place I was expecting it to be a lot bigger and more exciting.   My main issue is how early it closes and I hope that changes. Most places close around 7pm-8pm except a few that never seem to be open after 4pm like the sushi place.  It has a revolving list of stores with a few regulars.  If you are a craft beer person my suggestion is to get your food and eat it at the bar at Tanks and they have a good selection of locals beers.  On a nice day sit outside and watch the trains go by. Also note that they validate parking in the ramp for up to 90 minutes.  If you plan to stay longer than that my suggestion is to park somewhere else.

Three years since I last reviewed the 7th Street Public Market and it's matured a bit. On a busy Saturday morning with a cancer fund raiser on one side and a cultural festival to the other, the place was packed. Lots of people here at tables, eating, drinking, shopping. Impressive.  Vendors here offer all sorts of tasty treats including fresh customizable pizzas, draft local beers, pastries and breads, made-to-order crepes, fresh sushi, raw milk, awesome coffee and a wine shop. Wow!  Eat inside at one of the smaller/larger tables or take it outside near where the light rail stops.

Love this place, friendly people great options for anything you can think of (just about) Pure Pizza is awesome and good for you, NOW Tank*s Tap! Great local craft beer with great staff! Fun place to stop and have a beer and enjoy pizza or awesome sandwiches from Local Loaf. Either way there's something for everyone. I will for sure be stopping in more often!

Coffee, beer, wine, pizza, crepes, cheese, sushi, and so much more!  I'm sold!  7th Street Public Market is the home of Not Just Coffee, Local Loaf Bakery, Pure Pizza, Tank's Tap, Cloud 9 Confections, Hazelnuts Creperie, Orman's Cheese Shop, Viva Raw, and then some.    This place is always busy on the weekends but offers ample seating and free WiFi.  Don't be shy; share a table!  The market hosts various events throughout the week and on weekends.  It's a great place to relax over coffee, have breakfast, lunch, dinner, etc.  You'll see a wide variety of patrons; ranging from the uptown professional to the hipster coffee house lurker.  Business professionals and students alike take advantage of the "mobile office" concept to get some work done.  There's even a designated area to "plugin" if need be.  Vendors have changed out some over time, but the tried and true have stuck around.  The market has its own parking garage.  Once inside, be sure to validate your ticket to enjoy your first 90 minutes free of charge.  There's definitely a little something for everyone here.  I'd highly encourage anyone to check it out!

I am frequently asked, "Where should I take my ____________ who is visiting from out of town? I want to show them the city, but don't know where to start." My answer usually involves some variety of 7th Street Public Market.  a) validated parking for 90 mins (or just swing over to Queen City Q for a drink and have them validate if you're going to be there for a long time) b) incredible local food options including Local Loaf, Orrmans, Pure Pizza, Bonsai, etc. c) treats, treats, treats!! barCHOCOLATe, Cloud 9, Novel Sweets, Salts of the Earth, etc. d) drinky things from Not Just Coffee, the Sorting Table, Viva Raw...  There's so much more, including actual "market" type vendors. I love Saturday mornings, buzzing with activity, with additional vendors outside and kids running around everywhere. So if you're looking for a place to give someone the flavor of Charlotte as it's expanding into a more mature city, you simply must check out 7th Street Public Market.

The market was smaller than I had expected. I didnt get to try anything there but I was hoping for a bigger market with more variety of food and dessert. I do hope this place expands with more choices to choose from.

This is a local market with a great atmosphere, and great people. I typically shop at the market because I feel great after eating the food here rather than at a grocery store where almost everything is processed. The owner's are wonderful, hard at work and treating you like you are the boss, making you leave with a smile on your face. I highly recommend coming here, the only bad thing is that they are not open on sunday!

One of my new favorite places in Charlotte. I stumbled upon this place one day on a search for coffee. A lot of my great finds happen when I'm on a coffee hunt. I love that I can walk to this place from my apartment- I can't think of a better place to kill some time on a weekend. Sushi, Coffee, wine, cheese? what more can a girl ask for?? Well I guess I could go for some homemade soaps and delish pizza. This place has it all. When my roommate and I went it was pretty slow for some reason, but I'm not complaining. All the vendors we spoke with were happy and helpful. My coffee was Amazing ( I wasn't very surprised, I have had Not just Coffee before) Our sushi was fresh and filling and my dog seems to like his hamdemade soap.   Parking is validated for 90 minutes and some of the vendors have really well priced items. I'm sure I will be venturing to the public market again!

I love the concept and execution of this place... there is actually something for everyone here.  If there isn't something here for you, there is always people-watching!  Do have to warn you, this place is an assault on the senses.  The moment you walk in, you smell all sorts of goodness:  coffee, beer, soaps, fresh made pastries, it's pretty crazy.  You are also hit with a wall of sound, but in a good way... that just means it is bustling with activity with folks enjoying and making use of the market.  Just like you learn something new everyday, I always discover another corner of this place that I haven't tried yet - It maybe a 'special' one of the vendors is offering or an entirely new vendor in the space.  The space really celebrates the community and the ability to get fresh foods and goods.  They even hold events here like a holiday "sip and shop" where you can buy Christmas presents while enjoying beverages.   Definitely a great alternative to "big-box" shopping, having something like this in a thriving city is such a treat.  Parking in the deck is free for the first 90min if you get validated in the market, but you can easily get to it via Light Rail (stop is right outside) or just walk from uptown... ride a bike (B-cycle station right outside).

Well I got there about 3pm so everything was closing up by the time I got there but there were a few places still open.  Pure Pizza, Not Just Coffee and a few other places seemed to be busy yet.  There is also a fresh meat stand, a produce vendor and several specialty vendors.  Ended up buying just a beverage from Nelly's Naturals.   Seems like a decent place.   I'll need to come back here when the rest of the vendors are there.  And it's air conditioned unlike some other similar markets around town.  In this heat, that is a plus!

7th Street Market is gem to the Uptown area. If you can't make up your mind about what you want to eat, come here and surprise your taste buds. There's a variety of little eateries here... Including pizza. I can with the intent to grab some coffee and ended up trying a crepe too!   On a nice day, you can sit outside and catch the train south when you're finish if you want. #simplelife

I really appreciate that the 7th Street Public Market even exists, try to patronize the place at least once a month and it would be more often if we didn't live in Huntersville.  My favorite new addition is the Meat and Fish company which is owned by the LaVecchia's (yes, those LaVecchia's...).    They supply many restaurants in town and offer a nice, if pricey, variety of fresh seafood and grass fed beef for the retail customer.  They generally have Kobe beef too if you are into spending that kind of dough and always seem to have some interesting, unique specials.  Recent ones include whole Berkshire suckling pigs and this weekend, two versions of huge salt prawns.  Yesterday I bought two racks of St. Louis cut Berkshire pork spare ribs.  I dry rubbed and smoked them for four hours and they made a delicious dinner last night.  Again, pricey but, if you have never had any kind of "heritage pork", you will know why you spent that extra cash once you take the first bite.  SO much more rich flavor than what you get from a vacuum packed, mass produced rack you pick up from your local grocery.
